comments.commentBody:
Interesting take since the House has passed a great deal of legislation that sits languishing under the thumbs of Harry Reid as Majority Leader of the Senate.

Why aren't you also railing against Reid's intransigence?

Could it be for political reasons?

And as for money and power? The Democrats are pure and noble in that regard?

Come on, now, get in touch with reality.

Tom:

Especially Cryin' John Boehner, who keeps proving he is totally incompetent as Speaker of the House.

cool, yep, still waiting for accountability of both government and contractors for the ACA rollout.
Tim, only half the people usually go to the polls, that is one of the problems.
jhussey, do elections really create government anymore with finely tuned districts so incumbents can just about guarantee their reelection? BTW, midwest location is the great plains (you know, flyover country)
Owl, if you have read my past comments, I also rail against Reid. I am saying both parties have failed to do their jobs.
If the members of the House were accountable for their job performance, they would all be fired for failure to act.

sbm, GRACE KELLY was only 52 when she DIED???

WHH
For Mark Thomason:  Big Pharma...Republican???  Seems to me Big Pharma got together with Obama, who, BTW, happens to be a Democrat, to get this bill shoved down our throats.

Einstein:

More than just a spreadsheet, from the Congressional Budget Office:

http://www.cbo.gov/publication/44595

Here is a handy timeline on implementation of provisions by year, 26 of which have been in place since 2010:

http://kff.org/interactive/implementation-timeline/

ClearEye-

You, Paul Krugman and the CBO are missing the big picture. Most already-insured Americans are experiencing healthcare cost INFLATION.

Large segments of middle-class and working poor, small businesses and farms have seen costs skyrocket just to keep the same level of healthcare coverage. Dental healthcare coverage is through the roof.

We need numbers that tell the whole story.

Ummmm,

The bill was signed in 2010.

Exchanges started Oct 1, 2013.

Jan. 1, 2014 is the day Obamacare is supposed to truly and fully be open for business. That means it is also the first day the federal government will require most Americans to have health insurance.

Mr. Krugman, we normally love your opinions, somebody has to look at the positives but aren't you exaggerating a bit here?
Read the Jeremiah Book in the bible and you will know why. False prophets abound in this modern age.
The Republican party is so intent on making any proposal by the president fail, they have no time left for governance or leadership.

Poe's initials.  He wrote Eldorado.  Not that I actually knew that.  Fortunately, I knew all the crosses there and never saw the clue.  But I looked it up on xword info, and saw that every single EAP answer referred to Poe, so it became immediately obvious- after the fact, of course.

No, Martin, I'm not falling for that Route 66 stuff. Instead I'm going organic. As has been the case so often in the past 13 years, our Chicago family leaves to be with the in-law family. That leaves the wife and me alone. So we have a tradition of going to Ditka's for our Thanksgiving dinner and they do an amazing job. Ditka was not there today for the first time in ten years. He is at a golf tournament in Florida, if our waiter Carlos is correct. So we start with a beverage. And we take a picture with a cell phone and send it to both of our extended families. This is one of the pictures we sent. The wife has a Bombay Sapphire martini on the rocks (which you can see on the left). I start with something else, which is in plain view. You can also see the Ditka napkin to the right of my glass. So my avatar is what is in my glass. Good luck, Martin.

PS. That olive is stuffed with blue cheese.

PPS. As for the puzzle, I will deal with it's obscurities tomorrow.
Most of the media just repeat conservative talking points. Do't you know that there is no such thing as the "liberal media"?

Sleater--

Good letter. I contend that the people who keep spouting the 'fail' line neither ignore the truth, nor can't handle it--I think they want to obfuscate it. These are the exact same people who put 'public school' in front of the word fail too. It ain't accidental or mistaken.
yes

Always so refreshing to read your economically informed takes on the Affordable Care Act/Obamacare.

Perhaps you could let the reporters at this paper--the New York Times--know that the law and program (all of it) is not just a complete failure, as GOP partisans, and their establishment media stenographers on TV, the radio and the net keep proclaiming from one end of the US to the other.

All I keep seeing is Obamacare=FAIL, ad nauseam. Do the people who keep spouting this line just ignore the truth, or is that they cannot handle the truth?

The elder Paul's 30 year old staffer died of complications from pneumonia two weeks after the 2012 GOP debates. He didn't have health insurance. Knowing this, Ron Paul still ran a campaign against it. I don't know which Paul you've deemed less nutty, but I see both as equally heartless and selfish.

So, what is wrong with a government ruled by 'special interests'?  That's the way it has always been and will always be.  We get the government we deserve.  It really is that simple, and whining otherwise is a waste of time.

And Ryan and Paul and McCain, who want to shrink the Federal Government and reduce taxes, want money and power more than any democrat in Congress, or even equal to any democrat in Congress, because why?

The turkey was moist. The pie was great. The smiles and laughs were genuine. But the GOP will not let us even enjoy one day a year, for they thrive on anger and self-righteousness and venality.

Paul Ryan cares not one whit about the "budget" or "our children's future" or any of that poll-tested pap that Frank Luntz and the rest of the GOP ad-cabal pour forth from their muckraking machine. What Ryan and Rand Paul and sclerotic John McCain want is money and power and, most of all, people to pay attention to them.

I fear we have indeed not seen the worst of them yet...

Andrea E: "Doing nothing actually appears to be the least harmful action." Yes, sure: tell that to those receiving food stamps or unemployment benefits. Or to those without health insurance. Or to those made jobless by  sequestration or to those who'll be made jobless by the next round. Or to the undocumented still living in the shadows. Or to gays and lesbians who might just as well be out of fear of losing their jobs.  Know anybody like that?  If not, it's time to emerge from the cocoon. (Never mind that the ACA is working better than you're inclined to admit- vide Paul Krugman's current op/ed piece).
Don't let facts get in the way of a much needed feel-good moment for Team Obama.  Notice Krugman gave no actual numbers or growth rates.

Not sure how the WSJ defines "bottoming out" but the WSJ reported earlier this year ("Medical-Price Inflation Is at Slowest Pace in 50 Years") that health care costs rose by just 1% in the year prior to July, 2013, which is much lower than 3.9% in 2009.  The health cost trend is beginning to look like inflation in the overall economy, even 4 years after the recession.  It's peculiar that the ACA's most strident critics, who claim the law is so far-reaching that it will have devastating negative impacts, balk at the idea that such a far-reaching law could have anything to do with positive changes we can all observe.

J&J

The Opinion Page of the NYT isn't "Objective and Unbiased" either!

S9,

Right now we control the cost of Medicare by reducing the payments to the providers. That has the effect of raising the costs for everyone else.

Except for the fact that the American Enterprise writers in the WSJ called the president's claim that the ACA has contributed to the recent slow growth in health care prices and spending borderline "Nonsense*", this all sounds good.

They still believe the biggest driver of the reduction is the recession. Spending is projected to reach a record high of $2.9 trillion in 2013, 25% above pre-recession levels in 2007, and "according to health-care actuaries at the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, health-care spending will begin spiraling upward again starting next year, as the Affordable Care Act takes full effect."

It doesn't sound as though we should be celebrating anything at this point.

While acknowledging that the annual rate of spending increases has slowed, especially over the last 3 years, they also highlighted a decades-long history of decline:

"[a]nnual health-spending growth rates began to decline a decade ago. In 2002, health-care spending grew by nearly 10% in a single year. The growth rate dropped to 7.1% in 2004, 6.2% in 2007, and bottomed out at 3.9% in 2009—the worst year of the Great Recession, where it has stayed ever since. ObamaCare was enacted in 2010."

* "The Next ObamaCare Mirage", WSJ, 11/25/13.

**GOPers do demagoguery, not strategic planning.**

Best to get Darrell Issa to investigate the matter.

Liam "we" are very many (at least in the highly recommended comments in every comment series on the USA-Iran-Israel triangle) who would like to see a serious discussion in the NYT of the thoughts expressed by you as follows:

"Iranians decry Israel as a symbol of Western power projection which it was via the Balfour Agreement. 80 million Iranians don't care about blowing up 8 million."

We are told endlessly that Iran wants to destroy Israel and the President appears quite willing to discuss this thought with Benjamin Netanyahu. But the only place I can find any presentation of the thought that Iran has better things to do than attack Israel is in the highly recommended comments - every day.

The related subject is of course the fact that a single nuclear weapon sent by Iran on Israel would result in the obliteration of Iran that Hillary promised us she was ready to bring off if needed.

Not once in the NY Times has there been a column seriously discussing this rather basic subject. Why not?

Larry Lundgren Only-NeverInSweden.blogspot.com

Footnote: That is the editorial "we". It applies pretty much to Verifieds since you are able to file the high quality thoughts seen here and at Tim Egan's column when these columns appear on Times Wire. This reply at 05 56 Eastern Time filed en route to Gothenburg.

It may be demagoguery to the communist Chinese government and to the Iranian theocratic government to say the GOP will survive handily, and continue to win elections in the US.

It isn't to any republican American citizen.

From afar, the GOP has made the U.S. government look totally lame and dysfunctional. It's not pursuing policies to strengthen our economy but policies that weaken it. The U.S. is war-weary. The U.S. military needs refitting. Equally true in major European countries.

China has noticed. The U.S. has only a "navy in being" in an area much farther back. Its mere presence is supposed to make an aggressor take it into account. Given Republicans' focus on everything other than our national economic strength through a collaborative, equitable economy with a strong manufacturing arm and modern infrastructure, China dismisses our "navy in being."

The GOP is just as ignorant about Iran. Go back to 1908 when the Brits began raping Iranian oil wealth. In 1931, the Shah declared the oil concession void to get a fair deal. In August 1941, the UK and Soviets invaded Iran for a supply route.They put the Shah's son on the throne as their poodle. In 1953 the CIA and MI6 overthrew of the elected PM who'd nationalized the oil industry to fund the people's needs. That still inflames most Iranians.

Iranians decry Israel as a symbol of Western power projection which it was via the Balfour Agreement. 80 million Iranians don't care about blowing up 8 million Israelis. Iran wants the West to stop trampling its sovereignty. Nukes do that. Now they get a chance to prove they'll pull back if the West will collaborate instead of dominate.

GOPers do demagoguery, not strategic planning.

There is a simpler explanation that better fits the time line.

When Democrats are in office, costs are limited.

When Republicans are in office, costs soar.

Who gets those soaring costs under Republicans? Republicans -- insurance companies, Big Pharma, guys favored by the political appointees put in place all through the bureaucracy by Republicans.

So the reduction in this huge rip off is not due to the ACA. It is just due to throwing out the Republicans.

The corollary -- as soon as Republicans get back in, ACA or no, they'll do it again, and costs will soar again.

"Savings" are things taken from us. Things taken from rich Republican interests are just bad things happening to the Beltway crowd, to be reversed ASAP.

Hand up for SERUM and for issues in the northeast. I finally revealed a few clues so I could finish. I hate doing that. I should likely leaves blanks and come back, but the patience is not strong in this one, to paraphrase Yoda.
MOL, far as I know, lymph is just SERUM that finds itself in the lymphatic system, so I agree with Ted: PLASM is just plain feh-bulous.
Looking forward to it Howie...

That was a weird experience. Raced through almost the entire puzzle and got completely hung up in the northeast. Probably spent a good fifteen minutes there. Didn't help that I was watching the Godfather at the same time.

Biggest issue was the answer PLASM. Feh. The word is plasma. I know, it's a variant. Feh. So of course, I had serum, which is perfectly reasonable. Mere went in nicely, crossing the M, so I was quite sure it was right. Didn't help that I had RATA instead of ACTA. The cluing in that corner was plain obfuscation. Actually, nothing wrong with a little obfuscation. When I finally let go of serum, things slowly worked out, with plasm (feh) going in last.

I did enjoy this puzzle, especially the references to Mel Blanc. I may have mentioned my love of Bugs Bunny in past posts. Knew Puddy Tat immediately, but not how to spell it.

Some nice entries in this puzzle, like CORN COB. Loved the clue for that (inner ear?). But there was also some odd cluing. I suppose if you didn't know the proper names in the southeast, you could be up a tree. I didn't have an issue with this, but perhaps constructors ought to try and avoid packing a corner with these types of factuals.

Juliusa

You and your sister are better off than being on unemployment. Congratulations for doing the right thing for yourselves and for America!

Based on this theory, we did the right thing! My wife lost her $60K a year job, and now is working in a retail store for $9 an hour because that is all that's available. After taxes she takes home a little more than $200 a week. So we are MUCH better off than being on unemployment, don't you think Mr. Mulligan? I lost my job after 9/11 and now work for HALF my pay from back then since becoming a teacher. I love my work, and both of us would rather work than take unemployment. But these theories just prove the disconnect between the economic "experts" and the people they affect by espousing these ridiculous ideas. I took unemployment and medical program help while we needed it, and have not used it since. It got us through a tough time., and to think we should not help others that way who continue to suffer through a tougher time is spiteful and horrendous. I too studied economics and never heard such nonsense put forth throughout my MBA program or over the years I worked in business. We are truly losing our way as compassion society. Happy Thanksgiving, Mr. Mulligan.

Looks like objective economic reality, based upon facts, and how humans overtime react to incentives.

When we have incentives for employers and entrepreneur to not risk time, talent, energy and resources because of unreasonable interference by governments in the market place – such as the ACA , they reduce invests time, talent, energy and resources to create jobs. Also for the individual if it is easier to collect unemployment benefits from the government than have to take direction from others and have deal with co-workers and customers, show up at a place that is less comfortable than home and still basic needs provided – why not stay on unemployment for as long as it lasts?

For a better economy for all – change the incentives -- we all hurt when the incentives are not reasonable and properly aligned to reach some sort of fair optimization.

David

You may not like the assertion, but that doesn't mean it isn't true. The unemployed may find it unpalatable to move to california and pick crops, or Colorado and slaughter cows, but there are jobs to be had.

Greenie
You state "The only time that UI is a more viable choice is if the replacement job pays so little (clerking at Wal Mart or the dollar store?) that it makes financial sense to remain on UI and keep searching."

That is indeed the problem. If we stopped UI payments, people would take the job at Wal Mart, people would employed, and unemployment rates would be lower than today. What is wrong with that?

Seriously?

Do you think health insurance can be cashed in for food and housing?

Seriously? Is it cheaper to treat cancer in stage 1 or stage 4? How about diabetes; better to catch it early or late? Yes, more people will now have access to subsidized health insurance, but we were already providing healthcare for the working poor in the least efficient manner possible and passing those costs along to everyone else.

P.S. Unless you are part of the working poor, you've already benefited from your entitlement, e.g., tax break for employer-provided health insurance, Medicare, Medicaid, military medical system, VA medical system.

"Even if the emergency program is allowed to expire on Jan. 1, it will ‘be replaced by an even larger program — the Affordable Care Act — assisting the unemployed and others, including premium subsidies for health insurance."

Thanks for again PROVING that Obamacare is a massive entitlement program that will cause healthcare costs to explode. The CMS got it right, but of course the committed left still claims that the CBO proves the law will lower costs.

Seriously?  I don't understand why we don't have massive training programs...partnerships between schools and businesses.  I am for unemployment for those who can't a job.  But I would love to see the politicians in Washington and in states do serious work in partnership with private businesses (you know, those ephemeral job creators?) and high schools to train people for jobs/fields that are and will be available.  All the rest is just the same old blah blah blah.  We need job programs.
So very well said.
I WAS NOT USING THE ACA WEBSITE.    Lots of web sites do not work the way they should.  And sometimes, it depends on what browser you use.

The people who designed those sites are still fixing their own states' problems.

Also, they are not necessarily technology gurus and are not up to the task of stepping into the federal exchange project, figuring out what needs to be done and doing it.

"Cast not the first stone"
Amy is in denial. Of death, and of life.
My prayers go out to you, Amy, for your suffering.

It's not as bad as that makes it look.  Frankly, nobody knows for sure exactly why the labor participation is down. However, it's a pretty good guess that about half of it is retirees - the baby boomers are starting to fall, and that will continue and even increase over the next decade or so.  I've heard tell that some of it is people staying in or going back to school.  But yes, for sure some of it is people that just plain gave up.
